loans.name: Wahida

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. She is 48 years old, married and lives with five family members. Two of the family members work.

Wahida has cows producing milk so she has been selling dairy products since 1990. She has good experience breeding animals and has a good reputation. She is well known in her area.

She is requesting $1800 to buy a cow to milk. She aspires to have a large barn and to increase the dairy products so she can gain more profits and improve her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy a cow to milk.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites is 29 years old and is a married woman. She has two children aged 10 and 3. Her husband works as a farmer and security guard.

Marites is also a farmer. She helps her husband till their farm where they grow rice crops. According to Marites, their current earnings are about $150 per month. She does her best to keep their farm productive. She applied for a loan and plans to use it to purchase three sacks of seed and six sacks of fertilizers. Marites hopes for her family's living conditions to improve.

loans.use: to purchase 3 sacks of seeds and 6 sacks of fertilizers.

loans.name: Saru

texts.en:
Saru (pictured above), 59, runs a grocery store at her home. She lives approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. She is a widow with three sons and one daughter. Three are married and live outside the family home and another one is a garment factory worker.  

Saru hopes to buy additional grocery items to better respond to her customers' needs, so she is asking for her first loan of $600 to help her raise capital.

loans.use: to purchase additional grocery items for her inventory.

loans.name: Nguluwe

texts.en:
Nguluwe is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a fish selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. In addition she also sells coconuts, which contributes another source of income. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. Nguluwe dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the 20,000 KES she wants to purchase bundles of dry fish and coconuts for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of dry fish and coconuts for resale.

loans.name: Rhaida

texts.en:
Rhaida is from the village of Barangay 4, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 33 years old. Rhaida is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling caps, sandals, towels, t-shirts, blouses, kitchen utensils and flashlights in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twelve years and earns approximately $230 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rhaida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Rhaida is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stocks of blouses, kitchen utensils and home products. This  will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of blouses, kitchen utensils and home products.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To renovate the walls and ceiling of his shop.

loans.name: Nargis' Group

texts.en:
Nargis is married with three children: two sons and a daughter. Her elder son works in the fields and grows different seasonal crops. The 2nd one is a graduate by degree and works in a telecom company while her daughter operates her beauty salon at home and provides beauty services to her female clients. 

Her husband is a retired government employee. He receives a pension from the government every month. Nargis herself is a housewife, staying at home and doing her household responsibilities.  

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the betterment of her eldest son who wants to buy fertilizers, seeds and pesticides for his agriculture business.  He has been operating this business for the past four years and Nargis is hopeful that an investment will help him improve his business conditions further. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Nargis.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, seeds and pesticides for agriculture business.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma is from Gango, Ozamiz City. She is 58 years old and married to Artemio. They are blessed with five children, three of whom are already working and the rest are still studying. To make a living, Emma owns and operates a canteen store.  She makes and sells snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for one year and earns approximately $118 a month.

In January 2006, Emma joined Paglaum MPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC.

Emma is now requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients for her snacks and other delicacies for her business. This will be her 7th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients for her snacks and other delicacies business.

loans.name: Ou

texts.en:
The woman in the photo is Mrs. Ou, age 50. She lives in the Province of Kompong Tom in Cambodia, where she earns a living raising pigs. Since 2000, she has run this business, and it has provided her with income to get to her standard of living. She is married with eight children, five of whom are single and three are married already. 

Her husband helps her in raising pigs as well as catching fish. In order to earn extra income, Mrs. Ou will be using the loan to buy a second motorcycle for traveling needs because she and her family always pay for a motor taxi when they want to go out. That is why Mrs. Ou made the decision to ask for a Kiva loan.

loans.use: to buy a second motorcycle for traveling needs.

loans.name: Amale

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. She is 51 years old, divorced and lives with two family members, one of whom works.

Amale has been a tailor since 2000. She makes or repairs women’s clothing. She has good experience in this field and a good reputation and she is becoming well known in her area.

She is requesting $3000 to buy a generator and a sewing machine. She is aiming to gain more profits so she can improve her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy a generator and sewing machine.

loans.name: Jacklyn

texts.en: Jacklyn currently sells beans, she is 23 years old and married. Jacklyn took out a loan to stock more beans to sell. She hopes to open a big shop in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: to stock more beans to sell.

loans.name: Carol

texts.en:
Carol is from the village of Mandulog, Iligan City. She is 32 years old. Carol is widowed and has four adult children. She raises and sells goats & chickens. She also sells blouses, t-shirts & pants in her community. Carol has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2011, Carol joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Carol is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Carol from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI: 

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

location.town: Mandulog, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Kagarama Bakyara Tukore Group

texts.en:
Abdul, 54, has been a taxi driver for the last 16 years in Kagarama town council-Ntungamo. This business has been invaluable to him in many respects, principally in the provision of better welfare for his family of 22. 

Local folk describe Abdul as a gentleman with a happy-go-lucky disposition. This they say has endeared him to many people who travel from Ntungamo to other parts of Western Uganda. 

Abdul was at first engaged in an agro produce sales business. Like many people in Western Uganda, Abdul also ekes out additional income from a farming business. He says weekly this business nets him profits of 100,000 Ugandan shillings. He says with this loan, he is going to purchase spare parts for his taxi and also pay for overall repairs on it.

loans.use: to buy spare parts and pay for repairs on his taxi

loans.name: Socheat

texts.en:
Socheat (pictured above) is a garment factory worker. Her husband is a vegetable farmer. The couple lives along National Road No. 1, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia, and has two children--one son and one daughter. They are in school. 

Socheat asked for Kiva loans two times already. She now is requesting another loan of $1,000 to purchase additional farmland for her husband.

loans.use: to purchase additional farmland for her husband.

loans.name: Zeninanda

texts.en:
Zeninanda is from the village of Lugdungan. She is 62 years old. She is married and has three adult children. Zeninanda sells a variety of fresh fruits and vegetables in the local community. Zeninanda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2010, Zeninanda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Zeninanda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. Zeninanda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fresh fruits and vegetables to sell. 

This will be the third loan taken out by Zeninanada from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more fresh fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Savith

texts.en:
Savith is a motor taxi driver. His wife sells corn and mango. They have five sons. One is a carpenter, three are in school, and the fifth one is still young. The family lives along National Road Number One about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Savith hopes to change his business from motor taxi to tuk tuk (three-wheeled auto rickshaw), so he is asking for a loan of $1,200 to buy a tuk tuk.

Photo: Savith and his wife.

loans.use: to purchase a tuk tuk.

loans.name: Abdulrazaq

texts.en:
Abdulrazaq is a young man who is getting married this summer and needs to cover some of the expenses that he can't cover directly as he is an employee with a meager salary.

Abdulrazaq took out a loan from FATEN to pay for the wedding hall and chair rentA. to have the wedding on time.  Abdulrazaq is photographed in the picture above.

loans.use: to pay for the wedding hall and chair rental.

loans.name: Nadzua

texts.en:
Nadzua is a widow with two children who are adults. They own a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. For the past three years, Nadzua has been operating her grocery shop where she sells sukuma wiki (green vegetables) and potatoes at retail to her neighbors.

With the 30,000 KES she is requesting, she wants to purchase sacks of green vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes and onions. She dreams of expanding and becoming a wholesale supplier in the future. Nadzua decided to work with Yehu Microfinance to access funds to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of green vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes and onions.

loans.name: Phearun

texts.en:
Phearun (pictured here), 22, is single and lives with his sister and widowed mother in a village along National Road number two, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City.  

Phearun is a construction worker. He is asking for his first loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for commuting to work.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike for commuting to work.

loans.name: Hanilyn

texts.en:
Hanilyn is from the village of Karugmanan, Suarez, Iligan City. She is 25 years old. Hanilyn is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store, selling seafood products, including fish like milk fish and sardines, in the local community. Hanilyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $250 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Hanilyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

She is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish like mackerel and sardines. This will be her 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish like mackerel and sardines.

location.town: Suarez, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Wafaa

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. She is 39 years old, single, and lives with one family member.

Wafaa has been a tailor since 2009. She makes or repairs women’s clothing. She has a good experience and a good reputation and she is becoming well known in her area.

She is requesting $1500 to buy two sewing machines. She is aiming to gain more profits so she can improve her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy two sewing machines.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 47 years old. She owns rental houses made of iron sheets.  She rents out the houses to earn a living.  Being a married lady with three children, she works hard in her business so as to help her husband with household expenses.  She hopes to own rooms to rent for business purposes.  Mary testifies that since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been able to run her business well because of the business knowledge she gained from the trainings conducted by Faulu Kenya.  She needs 20,000 KES to build more rental houses.

loans.use: to build more rental houses.

loans.name: Veng

texts.en:
Veng (pictured above) and his wife are weavers. In addition, he is a fisherman. The couple lives on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Penh City, and they have a young son.  

Veng is asking for a loan of $200 in order to purchase fishing nets for his fishing business.

loans.use: to purchase fishing nets for his fishing business.

loans.name: But

texts.en: Mrs. But has one wooden kiosk where she sells many kinds of product. Since 2009, she has been running this sales business and has been earning around $2 per day to cover the financial needs in her family. To share responsibility, her husband works in the garment industry as a garment factory worker and he always gets a suitable salary each month. Mrs. But’s business really runs smoothly from step-to-step and she normally adds many clients every month. To take this good opportunity, Mrs. But will use her loan to purchase additional necessary inventories for her on-going selling.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is from the village of Mapulog, Naawan, Misamis Oriental. She is 51 years old. Susan is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, junk foods, shampoo, soap and beverages in the local community. She is also providing karaoke services. Susan has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $150 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Susan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, beverages and biscuits. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, beverages and biscuits.

loans.name: Nan

texts.en:
Nan (pictured with her loom) is a weaver. Her husband is a farmer and does construction work when he is not at the farm. Nan is asking for a loan of  $1,000 to purchase a motorcycle for her husband to drive to work.

The couple has two sons and one daughter. They are living on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle for her husband to drive to work.

loans.name: Grace Wanjiku

texts.en:
Grace has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last twenty-one years and earns a good income.  She is 49 years old and the single mother of three children.  

She was introduced to KADET LTD by one of her friends and this will be her fifth loan.  She paid all her previous loans well and in good time.  She plans to use the loan amount to buy seeds and fertilizer.

In future, Grace hopes to become a leading farmer in the Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Nawnie

texts.en:
Nawnie is from the village of Poblacion 3, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 49 years old, married, and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, she runs a business venture in the entertainment sector, operating a video karaoke business in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for a year and earns approximately $238 a month for these activities. 

Nawnie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. 

She is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP with which she will purchase another video karaoke for her entertainment business. This will be her 2nd loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase another video karaoke for her entertainment business.

loans.name: Beatha

texts.en:
Beatha is 32 years old, and she has six children who are 2 to 14 years old. All are in school except for the youngest. Beatha's husband is a motorcycle driver.

Beatja sells food stuffs such as maize, sorghum and beans. This business has enabled them to improve their standard of living and pay school fees for their children. She is requesting a loan to buy more food stuffs such as maize, sorghum and beans. With the profits she plans to renovate her house. Her future plans are to open up a wholesale store.

loans.use: to buy food stuffs.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda is from the village of Tuod, Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 53 years old. Yolanda is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store, selling bananas and coconuts in the local community. She is also providing motorela services with her husband as the driver. Yolanda has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2009, she joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Yolanda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional bananas and coconuts. This will be her 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional bananas and coconuts.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary currently sells groundnuts and simsim (sesame). She is 30 years old and married. She took out a loan to stock more groundnuts and simsim to sell. She hopes to open a shop in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: to stock more groundnuts and simsim (sesame) to sell.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is 30 years old and is a married woman with a 7-month-old child. Her husband works as a farmer and driver.

Rebecca got engaged in farming twelve years ago. Now she helps her husband maintain their farm. They primarily grow rice crops to sell. Rebecca does her best to help provide for the family. She joined CEVI, a KIVA partner, and applied for a loan of 10,000 PHP. She plans to use it to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies. Rebecca hopes for their harvest to increase.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en: Joshua is 23 years old and single.   He sells scrap metals to earn a living. He joined the Baraka Ukweli group in Faulu Kenya so that he would save his money and access loans easily, because the members of the group guarantee each others loans.  Through the group, he has requested 20,000 KES to buy scrap metals.  Joshua hopes to have a stable business in the future.

loans.use: to buy scrap metals.

loans.name: Wilfred

texts.en:
Wilfred is 26 years old, married to Pamela who runs a grocery stall, and they have one child. He owns a retail shop where he sells a variety of household items like rice,sugar etc.

Wilfred has been in this business for the last six years with an income of KES. 15,000 per month.T his is his first loan from KADET LTD, which he intends to use to buy more stock for the shop like rice,sugar, for sale. 

He hopes to grow his business and in future to own a supermarket.

loans.use: To add stock,eg rice,sugar,and tea leaves for sale.

loans.name: Houssam

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 26 years old, single, and lives with two family members.

Houssam opened a bakery in 2007 where he makes all kinds of bread and pastries. He has more than four years of experience and has a good reputation and he is becoming well known in his area.

He is requesting a loan of $1500 to buy a dough mixer and a generator. He is aiming to earn more profit so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy a dough mixer and a generator.

loans.name: Rawya

texts.en:
Rawya is a mother of two daughters and one son. Her husband is an employee with a decent salary and she is a housewife. Rawya borrowed money from her brother to pay her children's tuition fees earlier this year.

Rawya took out a loan from FATEN to pay back her brother and repay FATEN on a monthly basis as it is easier than repaying the brother at once. Rawya feels much better that she could repay her brother as he is not a rich man and this amount would help him.

Rawya's husband Mahmoud appears in the picture here instead of her as she is a religious woman.

loans.use: to pay children's school and college tuition fees.

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.en:
Rosalia is a farmer from the town of Banga, South Cotabato. She has been growing rice for 15 years. Rosalia earns by selling her harvest to rice traders. Rosalia also started raising pigs to augment her income. She built a small backyard piggery that she hopes to expand soon. Rosalia has requested a loan that she will use to purchase seeds, fertilizers and pig feed.

Rosalia is 50 years old and is a married woman with 9 children.  She hopes to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and pig feed

loans.name: Hisham

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 43 years old, married and has four children. He lives with eight family members. Three of the family members work. 

Hisham has had a bakery since 2000. Here he makes all kinds of bread and pastries. He has more than 10 years experience and he is well known in his area.

He is requesting $2700 for tiling the walls of his shop. He is aiming to gain more profits so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: to tile the walls of his shop.

loans.name: Antonina

texts.en:
Antonina is from the village of Dinas, Sinacaban, Mis. Occ. She is 63 years old, married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Antonina runs a business venture in the retail sector running a general store and selling a variety of different products in the local community.

Antonina has been engaged in her business for 15 years and earns approximately 1500 PHP a month for these activities. Antonina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. 

Antonina is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP with which she will purchase variety of products such as shampoo, toothpaste and soap etc. for her general store. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Antonina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of products such as shampoo, toothpaste, soap etc.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is 24 years old and single.  He sells scrap metal to earn a living.  He has operated the business for six years.  In the business, he has employed one person.  Peter has sustained his business for six years because of his hard work and dedication.  He hopes to grow his business in the future.  He has requested a loan for 20, 000 Kes to buy scrap metal.

loans.use: To buy scrap metal

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary  is 23 years old and single. She currently sells clothes. Mary is requesting  a loan to stock more clothes to sell. She hopes to buy animals and rear them in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: Stock more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Nasir

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 31 years old, married and lives with six family members. Three of the family members work.

Nasir has had a food market since 2005. He has five years of experience, a good reputation and is well known in his local area.

He is requesting $3,000 to buy a split air conditioner and to make sliding doors for his shop. He is aiming to gain more profits so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy a split air conditioner and to make sliding doors for his shop.

loans.name: Aralkul

texts.en:
Aralkul lives in Balykchi, a small town in the Isykul region of Kyrgyzstan. She is 51 and married to a contractor. Together they have a daughter and a son. The son studies at school and the daughter helps her mom with housework. 

Ten years ago Aralkul moved to Balykchi, and since then she has been growing various plants. Specifically, she grows raspberry bushes and vegetables seedlings in a greenhouse. By selling her plants, she generates 3000 soms per month and her business has improved the family’s living conditions. Each month Aralkul uses some of the proceeds to purchase cattle. Her loan request is to purchase two calves for breeding.  

In the future Aralkul plans to open a sewing workshop, where she will process wool. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase calves for breeding

loans.name: Phonn

texts.en: Selling a few fresh fish is the main activity of Mrs. Phonn. She always takes fish from her husband and other fishermen in bulk for a reasonable amount. The family typically generates a revenue of US$8 each day and has been in their business for over 10 years. Currently, Mrs. Phonn always uses her motorbike to pick up her fish to sell at the busy market but now her old motorbike has broken down while driving and her saving account is not enough to replace it. That is why Mrs. Phonn requested a loan. She will buy a new motorbike as well as more fish to continue selling.

loans.use: to buy a new motorbike and more fish to sell.

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy is from the village of Jampason, Initao, Misamis Oriental. She is 37 years old and married with one school-aged child. To make a living, Juvy owns a business making and selling honey from beehives extracted in her local community. Juvy has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Juvy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI and is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed like sugar and honey. This will be the second loan taken out by Juvy from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI an of accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients like sugar and honey

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase bundles of clothes for her boutique.

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 23 years old, married and lives with six family members. Two of the family members work. Hussein has had a shop to sell mobile and phone accessories since 2006. He has four years of experience.  He has a good reputation and is well known in his area.

He is requesting $3,000 to buy a split air conditioner and a photocopier machine.  He is aiming to gain more profits so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy a split air conditioner and a photocopier machine.

loans.name: Rosalyn

texts.en:
Rosalyn is 29 years old and married with two children, aged 9 and 5 years old. She is a farmer who has been growing rice for five years. She tills her own land and prepares it well making sure her crops grow healthy. She also opened a sari-sari (variety) store to help meet her family's daily needs. Rosalyn earns 7000 PHP per month from her rice farm and store.

Rosalyn's loan will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizer, and other farm supplies. In the future, Rosalyn hopes to start another business. She wants to save for her children's future.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora is 52 years old. She is married with four children. She lives at Magsaysay, Baliangao with her husband and children. Her husband is a farmer. In order to help her husband, she runs a grocery store. Nora is able to earn a monthly net income of 4500 out of her business. She has been operating her business for more than 10 years   

In 2006, Nora joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve both her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting her third loan of 40,000 PHP to purchase new stock for her grocery store. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family and to save for the future of her children.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for her grocery store

loans.name: Kephar

texts.en: Kephar is 25 years old and married with a one-year-old child. He runs Harvard retail shop. He started the business three years ago after leaving his previous job. He has employed one person to assist him in his tasks. Kephar is focused on his business and he hopes to grow it into wholesale. He has been guaranteed a loan of 20,000 Kes by his group members in Faulu Kenya.  He will use the loan to buy rice, beans and sugar for his store.

loans.use: To buy rice, beans and sugar for his store

loans.name: Reida

texts.en: Reida is 21 years old and single. She borrowed a loan to stock more sugar and beans to sell. She hopes to buy goats and chickens in the future with the extra profit from her business.

loans.use: to stock more sugar and beans to sell.

loans.name: Jose

texts.en:
Jose is from the village of Labi, Dikilaan, Iligan City. He is 49 years old. Jose is married with three school-aged children. Jose has a service-based business providing motor or habal-habal services to local community members. He also runs a retail store with his wife. Jose has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Jose joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jose has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Jose is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the service. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Jose from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools needed to maintain vehicles.

location.town: Labi, Digkilaan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Ron

texts.en: Mrs. Ron, 42, is a local farmer who has had a farming business for years. She is married to Mr. Sary, age 39, who is currently planting a variety of products to earn a living. This couple has now four single children. One of her children works as a local farmer also. She wants to plant potatoes while the heavy rain is coming. Due to the lack of money, Mrs. Ron decided to seek a loan to purchase farming materials such as seeds, insecticides, and other supplies to begin a farming business for her child.

loans.use: to purchase farming materials such as seeds, insecticides, and other supplies

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is a married woman with four children, three of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor running water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a business selling home products such as cutlery and plates. Her potential customers are neighbours and passersby. Halima faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding it in the future. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase additional cutlery and plates for resale. She decided to join Yehu because of the efficiency of the loan products.

loans.use: To purchase cutlery and plates for resale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 27 years old, and married with three children. She runs a retail shop. In addition, she provides tailoring services to supplement her income. She has sustained her business for ten years because of her good customer service. In the future, she hopes to grow the business into wholesale. She has requested 20,000 Kes to buy sugar, rice and corn flour.

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice and corn flour.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is 26 years old and married to Josphat who is a security officer. They have four children. Lydia sells curios in Westlands, Nairobi. She has been in this business for the last three years and earns an income of KES.18,000 per month.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend. Lydia has applied for her first loan which she plans to use to buy more curios for sale.

Lydia will use the expected profits to pay school fees for her children; she hopes to join international curio exporters in the future.

loans.use: To buy more curios for resale.

loans.name: Neron

texts.en:
Neron is from the village of Sardab, Digkilaan, Iligan City. He is 31 years old. Neron is married with four school-aged children. He provides motorcycle or habal-habal transport to local community members. Neron has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Neron joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. Neron has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials needed to provide his transportation services. Neron is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase the tools needed to maintain the equipment. This will be his second loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools to maintain his transportation vehicles.

loans.name: Samara's Group

texts.en:
Samara is a young leader of this group. She is 22 and married. Her husband is employed; his monthly salary is 6000 soms. Samara has a newborn baby. In order to earn money to supplement the family budget, she takes orders at home and sews Kyrgyz blankets, pillows, clothes and dressmaking patterns. She started this business five years ago. Samara earns 5000 soms per month. With the money received from the loan she wants to purchase fabric and other materials needed for sewing. In the future Samara plans to save money to purchase furniture for her home.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fabric and materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, corn flour and rice for her food stall business.

loans.name: Taj's Group

texts.en:
Taj is a 52-year-old housewife who prefers staying at home and doing her household work. Her husband is a farmer by profession and grows different seasonal crops on his small piece of land. He is a very hard working person and mostly works until late evening to get the desired output from his crops. 

Taj is the mother of two daughters and a son. Her son works with his father in his agriculture business and her daughters stay at home. Taj couldn’t educate them due to poor financial conditions. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy fertilizers, seeds and pesticides to get better crops from his land and earn more profits. Taj is hopeful that her husband’s business will grow by investing the loan money into it, which will result in a better financial living standard for her family.  

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Taj.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, seeds and pesticides

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena is from the village of Tigbao, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 46 years old and married with two children who are grown and married. Elena's business is selling fish. She has been engaged in her business for 19 years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month. 

Elena joined PMPC to gain access to financial services. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. Elena is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, with which she will purchase more fish to sell in the market. 

This will be her sixth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

    Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a washing machine

loans.name: Fazila

texts.ru: Фазила проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 53 года. Замужем, имеет 8 детей. У нее среднее образование. Она занимается торговлей на рынке "Дехкон". Арендует торговую точку, где продает рис и маш. Этим видом деятельности занимается 12 лет. Кредит берет для покупки новых сортов риса.
texts.en: Fazila lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. She is 53 years old, married, and has eight children. She has a secondary education. She trades in the market called “Dekhon.”  She rents a shop where she sells rice and mung beans. She has been doing this for twelve years. She is taking out a loan to buy new varieties of rice.

loans.use: to buy new varieties of rice.
